comments.text:
+Viva Las Channel
It is counter intuative to say that the European Union was created by a 
Nazi. Because the first element that brought rise to the European Union was 
for France and Germany to share their coal production to make another war 
between them impossible on an economical standpoint.

I see alot of people making assumptions about the European Union after just 
having watched this video (+ having some basic information about it). I 
believe that those people never had to study about the EU in school, it 
takes a few weeks to really understand everything about it and then it 
simply makes sense.

It's the first intiative in European history that crosses the 
cultural/economical and political gap in Europe. Where the goal is for the 
entirety of Europe to have a strong and modern economy. In order to do 
this, richer countries dump money into the ones that need more development. 
Not as some form of solidarity but because it'll help these richer 
countries in the long run. Reducing immigration coming from the East and 
for better/more trade across the continent.

Furthermore it's simply necessary to compete with growing economical 
nations such as China. And it works, the EU is the biggest economical force 
in the world at this moment and every new country that joined has advanced 
in overal development and economical value. (Hence why there's a waiting 
line)

One of the reasons why the European Union gets a bit of a bad reputation is 
because national politicians usually say "We have to increase the tax on 
this because the European Union tells us to do so" while they cash in the 
improvements that the EU makes for themselves saying "We managed to lower 
the tax on that.". They tend to do this right before elections to protect 
their image whilst following European regulations.

I can understand that some outsiders might have a negative view about the 
EU because it seems so complex and they think that there's a complete chaos 
across the continent. All I can advice those is to come live here for a 
year.

I'm not telling you to think that the EU is great but atleast widen your 
view first and look at the bigger picture before making a statement.
comments.author: JeroenMW2

comments.text:
no, that is not the problem, the ECB only borrows money to banks, not 
governments, the reason the Greek economy failed was that they lied for 20 
years to the European Central Bank about how high their debts were, so the 
ECB allowed the Greek National Bank to loan more money to the Greek 
government.

The name ECB is actually a wrong name, because it has some of the functions 
of a national bank, like setting the interest rates which showed up in the 
news recently, but she has no actual money. The ECB is like the club of 
united national banks(not just the Eurozone). The ECB also set the rules 
for the size of national debts, no more then 3% in a single year and no 
more then 30% of the GDP. Both of those rules were broken as shown when the 
Greek crisis saw the light she had a debt of 100% of her GDP. When we went 
in the books to find out what happened the 3% was broken since 1978. This 
is when the Greek crisis started it started in at the latest the 1980's, 
but Greece chose to ignore the problem, just like they are still doing by 
blaming others.

That is why the Greek economy failed, it wouldn't even have mattered for if 
Greece was in the Euro or not. The only difference that would have made is 
that the Euro, even though Greece was a member, kept a stable course and 
did not get influenced noticeable by the Greek crisis whereas if Greece 
still had the Drachma, the currency would have fallen to an exchange rate 
of 1 Euro to 10.000.000 drachma or so. That in turn would have been 
(slightly) better for the Greek export but still a huge disaster for the 
Greek government, wealth and banking system. But then again, if Greece 
still had the Drachma, the EU might not have been so easy with financial 
aid.

comments.text:
You assumed correctly when you said I was Dutch. The reason I know the 
facts of the EU well and the economic picture come from several things. 
Firstly I was employed by the European Commission as a Rural developer in 
Romania, secondly I now work in the European Parliament for one of the 
Dutch political parties and last because I am studying International 
Economics & Languages (no English is not one of those languages).

I share your fear for the UK, I know what I am going to say now is going to 
upset some people but to me it feels like the people in the UK didn't get 
the memo that the once great British Empire is gone. That they still feel 
superior to countries like Estonia or Germany, and since the EU treats them 
in the same manner doesn't feel right to them. While in fact, the UK has 
the 3rd largest number of seats in the European Parliament, only Germany 
and France have bigger numbers since they obviously have a bigger 
population, this is how modern democracy works. Now imagine how a country 
like Sweden feels. They pay enormous amounts to the EU yet since they have 
a population of 9 million they get a small representation in the 
parliament. In fact the British one is more then 6 times as big. But the 
funny thing is, the countries that actually have reason to complain, don't.

As to your plan to study in Germany, first of I think it is a great idea, 
you will learn a lot more then just what they teach you in the university, 
as stated as before I lived abroad for quite some time and the hard part 
for me was to get used to the Netherlands again, everything seemed weird. 
Although the European Union has some great programs to support you in this, 
like the Erasmus exchange project(just google), you don't actually need the 
EU for that. Countries are showing a similar trend that they always want to 
improve their knowledge facilities and resources. So no doubt there will be 
a German program that really benefits you to study in Germany!
comments.author: Pieter van Vollenhove

+Viva Las Channel Have you heard of a group called the Netto-payers of the 
EU, there are in total 5 countries where the money to the EU is greater 
then the money and (economic & funding) profits received from the EU. Just 
5 who make up the difference in balance for all the other countries at the 
end of the year.

These 5 countries are, Sweden, Denmark, Germany, The Netherlands and 
Belgium. These countries lose physical money to the EU the rest gains 
money, but they see long time benefits for their own country so they agree 
to it.

From your name I interpret you're Spanish? The biggest investors in Spain 
are the Netherlands(14,2% of total), followed by 2nd place the EU(12,4% of 
total), after that the UK, France and Germany. this top 5 invest  65,4% of 
al foreign investment of Spain, In the top 10 are 3 other EU countries, 
Switzerland and Mexico(with a cute 559 million Euro's). Do you really think 
these countries would do this in such a terribly insecure economic climate 
Spain is in right now if they 'just' wanted to suck out your last cents? 
No! they want you to develop again, have a stable economy again! Is this 
safe for them? No! They are taking a huge risk because it simply might 
disappear into thin air! They are not investing millions, these number of 
each of the top 5 goes into Billions!

Spain contributes almost 9 billion euro's to the EU yearly, yet receives 13 
billion euro's from the EU yearly, without the previously mentioned 
investments. Does Spain ever hear that they are a drain on the EU? Don't 
think so. In fact of all the countries hit by the Financial crisis Spain 
received help quickest and least disputed even though they carry no direct 
benefit to the EU!

+HellenicArmedForcesHD Mostly to paying due interest I presume; IMF, 
banks,private loans(state obligations), Salaries and refilling a national 
reserve. Using the money to keep everything going as it was was 
unrealistic. Since it would not 'fix' the problem which is that the Greek 
expenses > income. That needs to change. Well, it can stay bigger but it 
must be reasonable. And as the situation was, it was nowhere near 
reasonable.

In 2004 the Greek debt was 100% of her GDP, today it is somewhere near 
170%. To compare, the Netherlands as of this year received a fine from the 
EU because of the national debt being too big. The Dutch debt is predicted 
to be 43% of her GDP at the end of this year(after the financial crisis). 
Maybe this gives a bit of insight of how big the Greek debt was. Sure the 
Dutch GDP is more then twice as big than the Greek GDP, but it's measured 
relatively to the countries GDP since this means the Netherlands can pay 
bigger interests and repay bigger loans.

reasoning which renders an argument invalid. 3. Faulty reasoning, Oxford 
Dictionary) I've given you such a clear example on how to actually make an

Greek. If anyone should be happy to be in the Union it is Greece. Since the 
eruption of the Greek Debt crisis Greece received a staggering 380 billion 
Euro's(380.000.000.000 that's a lot of zero's) in financial aid from the 
European Union alone. That is equal to the entire GDP of Austria and 
Finland Combined! GDP is the total value of all goods and services produced 
in a country in a year.

That means you, my friend received 34.500 Euro in person from the European 
Union. As did your neighbour, and the guy living across the street, in fact 
every Greek received this amount of aid since 2009. Who paid this? Well me, 
TopCuber, robert smith, and the rest of the Europeans. So maybe we are 
'useless monkeys', but for (here comes one of those nasty arguments again) 
sending our money as aid to save a country that apparently doesn't even 
want to be saved.

This paragraph is actually for TopCuber; No, unfortunately we do need 
Greece. They are in the Eurozone and it is unpredictable what would happen 
would Greece return to the Dogma. Companies would massively lose interest 
and confidence in Greece, without the stability provided by the Euro. What 
would you care the Greek economy failed? Well, especially with members who 
have been in the EU for over 15 years, our economies are so heavily

We've seen this happen in the 70's and 80's. Where the (West-)German 
economy crashed and dragged the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and France 
with her in that crash. Now we are even further entangled, no one wants to 
find out what will happen once a country actually crashes again, neither do 
you, believe me.

comments.text:
I think it has more to do with history.

Australia and Canada have always kind of been one (respectively of course). 
At first a certain Group of colonies and from pretty much the momen they've 
been indipendent, they joined together. Don't want to go much into that, 
though, I know only little.

In Europe on the other hand, every conflict, every war we've ever fought 
here (with exception of civil wars) has been about "No, I prefer to keep my 
land to myself, thank you very much" and via such a long history mainly 
defining each other over our differences, it has manifested in our minds, 
that the other countrys are fundamentally differen from us (And they are. I 
mean, come on.). Wich in turn leads to the more simple answer:

We just don't want to. We want to benefit from each other as much as 
possible. But being grouped in with them all? Lose an international 
apperance? Being he same nation as 'insert whatever you feel like'. No 
benefit is worth that. (I'm sure you can think of examples.)
That may sound kind of harsh, I realize, but htink. Because you like 
someone as a neighbour, doesn't mean, you want to move in with them.
comments.author: Jack S.

comments.text:
Because nobody speaks French or Portugese or Polish. Consider having a 
joint government with Somalia. For real. Nothing changes but you now vote 
for a joint government. How would that work? How can people that are 
largely ignorant of each other be one people?

A European public does not exist, neither does European citizenship besides 
formal rights. A German, French, Polish... guy is concerned with German, 
French, Polish, ... issues, watches German, French, Polish,... television 
and is not concerned with the EU except as an interference and annoyence 
when it comes to national legislation. You are not a European. You are 
British. Or Italian. You can go there without a pasport. Oh great. Not that 
different from going there with a pasport. For vacation only. It's not your 
country. It's still foreign. Lack of border does not change that. And if 
you work there, you a Foreigner working in a Foreign country and everbody 
sees it that way.

Tell that a New Yorker working in California? :D

European "citizens" cannot organize politically, or have a public 
discussion. If France changes same sex marriage laws, that's infotainment 
in the evening program. You might talk about it. But not with a Frenchman. 
And you don't really give a shit about it. It happens in another world. The 
EU ist not a federal country. Not anymore than the WTO is.

What really drives the EU is an interesting question I cannot really 
answer. It is sometimes discredited as an "elite project" which is driven 
by national governments but not their people. And that seems plausible to a 
certain extend. Governments are certainly concerned about influence, trade 
relations, etc. and it makes sense to join forces to gain more influence in 
the world.
That is what the EU is. Bringing the countries of Europe in line, because a 
collective decision has more force than a singular one. But even that often 
fails. Regardless, European heads of state seem to have a kind of "do or 
die" mentaltiy about this, and gain at least some support for it. It's 
certainly not the whole story but "a desperate persuit for global 
significance" is certainly a more fitting description of the EU than "a 
happy process of integration and people coming togehter tearing down 
borders".

I am not a historian but compare that to the US. The states had a common 
goal to keep indepence and stuff, but also where somewhat similar enough in 
values and motivations to join forces at least in emegerncy. But well, not 
entirely. Like a somewhat different econmy in north and south. HEY GUESS 
WHAT! It's civil war.
And now picture that with not a north and south being "a little bit 
different" (I have to downplay the differences because in comparison they 
just seem non-existent when you compare EU states), but everything being 
hugely different east and west and north and south and center and beyond 
the mountains and off the shores...

That there even is a process of common legislation and the worst that 
happens is people getting a little bit grumpy and occasionally light some 
trash containers actually seems quite impressive now. What I am saying is 
the EU manages much more than you maybe would expect it to archieve. It's 
not becoming a nation anytime soon.

And that actually seems fine to me. Economic cooperation and free trade of 
goods and services worked fine for decades without me having to agree with 
some Polish, British guy about human rights, anti-terror legislation, free 
press or what kind of shit teenagers are allowed to put into their cancer 
sticks or having a stupid common flag.

comments.author: UltimatePisman

comments.text:
+UltimatePisman
What is NLD supposed to mean? Netherlands Dollar? In the Netherlands, they 
payed with the Gulden (short: fl.), not the dollar.
Also: 0.37 fl. for a cup of coffee is absurd. That might be realistic if it 
was a cup of coffee that you made at home.
Plus: the main reason everything is more expensive now than it was back in 
1995 is inflation. In fact: unlike what the vast majority of people think, 
the Euro has not made everything more expensive. Some products increased in 
price (most notably consumptions in cafés and restaurant, which is why the 
cup of coffee is a bad example), but other didn't, or even lowered, and in 
the end, it is probably a wash.
Also note that the Euro is a much more resilient currency than most of the 
individual European currencies ever were, so inflation is kept much more in 
check, so in the end, the Euro will be to our benefit
comments.author: Bram Claes

+I am a Leftist I'll just respond to one of your comments or I'll be here 
all day. You say congestion is about "the general use of cars", suggesting 
it has little or nothing to do with immigration. Sorry, but that is 
illogical. The foreign-born population of the UK, from the 2010 census, 
stands at over 7 million, or 12% of the total population. This represents a 
50% increase on the previous decade. Seven million, and many more to come 
when others, such as Turkey, eventually join the EU. And my guess is that 
the influx of Romanians and Bulgarians will kick off come Spring. Clearly, 
a substantial number of these people will have cars, and that's an awful 
lot of cars. Build more roads, perhaps? Who pays for them? We're skint. And 
do we really want even more of our shrinking countryside polluted? It's bad 
enough that snake-oil salesman Cameron seems to have given the OK to build 
on greenfield rather than brownfield sites, no doubt because it's more 
profitable for his business buddies. I'll leave it there. House to decorate 
- though unfortunately neither suburban nor detached.
comments.author: dunholm1

comments.text:
+dunholm1 Just so you know the most densely populated country in Europe is 
the Netherlands and while we are second, France, Germany, Belgium, 
Luxembourg and Denmark all have similar population densities  so this 
notion that the UK is somehow full isn't entirely accurate. As for things 
like the NHS, schools and roads this is also a combination of myths and 
hypocrisy. Many hospitals (including one of my local hospitals) would have 
closed if it were not for the influx of staff from Europe, roads are 
congested worldwide its about the general use of cars. Stopping immigration 
will not solve that but a mass investment in public transit will. Schools 
however are in trouble but I attribute that more to chronic underfunding 
than immigration. Our schools have been in bad shape long before the 
arrival of eastern Europeans. And finally there are houses. this one 
particularly annoys me because it seems to be something the British are so 
inept at. In Britain we seem to have to not only own our homes but they 
must also be typical suburban detached homes. In damn near every other 
developed state (including America where there is absolutely no shortage of 
space) there are far higher %s of people living in apartments  which are 
much more space effective and much more rentals (which leads to a better 
more controlled rental market that makes it more affordable). This leads to 
some excellent innovation with homes. Like in Germany the government backs 
a program where a small group of people collectively employ a architect to 
renovate a old industrial building or communist apartment block to more 
modern luxurious standards, and then they all move in to one of the 
respective units. However in Britain most brownfield sites are left 
abandoned. then there is the issue of using private development companies. 
Developers are currently sitting on vast tracks of land but wont develop it 
until conditions are more favourable, in Holland however the government 
itself just employs contractors to build it (thus cutting out the 
unnecessary middle man). this has been so effective in Holland entire 
cities have been built entirely by the government. 
There are literally dozens of solutions to the problems you quote and 
stopping EU migration is not one of them.
comments.author: I am a Leftist

time. Cheers from a "mainlander", who's on a "sinking ship", condemned to 
be ruled by the personification of evil and whose only point in life is to 
restrict "british freedom". Excuse me now, I feel the need to wash my hands.

comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+dave19941000 Wow, a book! You trying to drown me in statistics? And it is 
only 5% of our firms which export to the EU. You have confused "firms" with 
"exports". And with London being the world's largest financial centre ( 
though NY may argue the point), and by GDP Europe's largest city, my 
statement that 60% of the FTT would have been paid by the UK is indeed an 
accurate one. But enough. Shall we just leave it there? I'm actually 
beginning to wonder if you are one of those "public opinion monitors" the 
EU was thinking of funding to monitor public conversations and "join in and 
influence the conversation" by "deconstructing myths" (so-called) about the 
EU. You are like a terrier after a rabbit, and seem to have an endless 
stream of pro-EU statistics at your fingertips. Strange, that, for I 
believe you have stated elsewhere that you are from "across the pond". 
Having a general interest in these matters, as I do, is one thing, but 
pounding out whole reams of material quite another. So let us go on our 
merry but different ways. You think the EU is wonderful, and I won't be 
happy until we Brits return to governing our own country without any 
foreign interference. Enough said.
comments.author: dunholm1

comments.text:
+dunholm1 "That Britain is doing fairly well at the moment is my point."

No it isn't, it's a blatant contradiction to your point.

"Only around 5% of our firms export to the EU, yet all have to abide by 
these regulations,"

Actually, 38.9% of British exports go to just the 5 EU members that the UK 
trades the most with (and of the top 10 only the 2nd most exported 
to nation is not an EU member). And then there are the imports, which the 4 
most active EU members make up 29.5% of imports (the only ones in the top 6 
are China in 2nd and the US in 4th). So no, it isn't "5%", it isn't even 
close.

"Also, we trade more with the rest of the world than any other member 
state."

So you would leave your largest single market for ease of doing business 
with ones which are comparatively insignificant? Free trade deals won't 
just appear, even when it is a single state they take years to negotiate. 
Best case scenario you set all of the dozen or so trade deals currently 
being negotiated or ratified in the EU back 10-20 years for the UK, if the 
nations they are with bother to try again at all. When the best case 
scenario is worst then the Status Quo, only the crazy try.

"free of over-regulation this can only grow further."

Regulations on trade for the British economy went down after joining the 
EU, but what's reality to UKIP supporters?

"Continental Europe will do what is best for continental Europe, and an 
increasing number here are fed up of their almost daily interference in our 
affairs."

I'm not sure which is more surprising, the fact you think of the 
mainlanders as a single group, or the fact that you take issue with less 
then 10% of laws effecting the UK being passed by the European Parliament. 
Either way seems more a reactionary thought then a thought our one.

"The efforts to introduce a FTT, 60% of which would have been paid by the 
UK alone, is a case in point. "

The UK is not even participating in the FTT, and there are 17 member states 
blocking it, and it requires unanimity to pass. And given what would be 
taxed, there is nowhere near 60% of it which would come from the UK, unless 
Germany, France, the Scandinavian nations and the Benelux nations had their 
financial sectors shrink by 99% between now and a time the tax could be in 
effect if it passes. Not only are you talking out of your ass, you're 
pulling numbers out of it.

"In good EU fashion they'll try to introduce it through the back door, 
probably through some change in the banking laws on the pretext of reigning 
in those institutions for the "public good"."

Given the type of law it is, there will be no means of passing it without 
unanimity. The EU system might not be perfect, but like all functional 
democracies there are some things which just can't pass.

"If it's to leave, then trade would carry on much as before but we'd have 
retaken our right to self-determination."

There's also the increase in price for a significant part of imports (much 
of which is food), and a reduction in exports across the board (the tariffs 
for getting them into the EU would probably be larger then the domestic 
prices for them). So no, it would "carry on much as before".

Churchill also said "we must created a United Europe, one strong and free 
of outside influence. A United States of Europe"

You can try and claim that the UK is not part of Europe, but geographically 
and culturally the statement is untrue.
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+dave19941000 That Britain is doing fairly well at the moment is my point. 
And this despite our huge trade deficit with the EU and the costly 
over-regulation. Only around 5% of our firms export to the EU, yet all have 
to abide by these regulations, such as those on the environment. Out of the 
EU we'd set our own rules based on what is best for us. Also, we trade more 
with the rest of the world than any other member state. Again, free of 
over-regulation this can only grow further. Continental Europe will do what 
is best for continental Europe, and an increasing number here are fed up of 
their almost daily interference in our affairs. The efforts to introduce a 
FTT, 60% of which would have been paid by the UK alone, is a case in point. 
Personally, I don't think they'll give up on that. In good EU fashion 
they'll try to introduce it through the back door, probably through some 
change in the banking laws on the pretext of reigning in those institutions 
for the "public good". All we anti's want is a referendum. An opportunity 
to democratically decide for ourselves the future of our countries and 
their people. If the vote is to stay in, so be it. If it's to leave, then 
trade would carry on much as before but we'd have retaken our right to 
self-determination. It really is that simple. As Churchill said, "We have 
our own dream - we are with Europe, but not of it --- interested and 
associated, but not absorbed". And that is my view precisely.
comments.author: dunholm1

comments.text:
+dunholm1 Alright I'm only going to address the issue of the economy 
because everything else is redundant at this point.

China's economic growth is slowing down, and doing so fast. I'm not sure if 
you noticed but their economy isn't exactly a stable one (their 2012 
projections for Iron consumption by 2025, for example, came under harsh 
criticism for exceeding industry production projections for the entire 
world. A little hard to believe that is going to happen given the laws of 
physics). China's economy has been slowing down, with last year being the 
slowest year of growth in the past 20, and the year before that holding the 
same title. It's Japan's 80s boom all over again.

As for India, given the state of their economy 20 years ago 38% growth in 
the past 10 years is no surprise (the country has surpassed Canada's 
economy last year, a country with 1/35th their population).

It's also funny you use 1980 as a point of reference to show how "far the 
EU has fallen", given that it was before the US/Canada economic boom of the 
80s, the Japanese boom of the 80s, the South Korean boom of the 90s, the 
Taiwanese boom of the 90s, the modernization reforms in China, the 
modernization reforms in India, the 80s reforms in Latin America, the 
economic stabilization of Africa during the late 80s until now (relatively 
speaking of course), the UAE oil explosion, the transfer from communism to 
capitalism in Eastern Europe, Mexico's economic boom of the 90s, 
Australia's boom which is still going strong, and a few relatively minor 
booms around the world.

That's the thing about being a modern, continent sized economy (which is 
still the largest just with the Eurozone), when 2 other continent sized 
economies have a boom (Japan, North America), and dirt poor nations begin 
to catch up to the industrialized world, the proportion of the world 
economy the largest economies controls shrinks. In fact in the case of 
Western Europe it has been doing so consistently since the mid 50s.

The fact of the matter remains, economic growth is still persistent in the 
EU, it's only at levels to be expected of a 1st world economy, and any 
economist who will tell you 8% or even 6% consistent growth should be 
expected is unemployed with good reason. On a side note: since 1980 the 
economy of the UK has grown by about 400%, and 2014 is expected to be see 
the largest economic growth since 2007, so are you telling me that a 400% 
increase over 34 years is a bad thing?
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+dave19941000 Another recent poll shows 49% want out as against 40% who 
want to stay in. A decade ago almost 70% were in support of EU membership 
in every poll. The trend is obvious, and continuing to swing in only one 
direction. That should not be happening when you consider that all the main 
political parties and much of the media, including the BBC are pro-EU and 
constantly pumping out EU propaganda. As for growth, over recent years the 
Indian economy has grown by almost 30%, and the Chinese economy by around 
50%. Currently, it seems to be engaged in buying America and large chunks 
of the rest of the world. During the same period the EU has stagnated. In 
1980 it had a 36% share of world GDP. It is estimated that by 2020 that 
figure will have shrunk to 15%. I'd call that a "sinking ship". It is also 
highly inefficient. Look at the idiocy which is the CAP and how it inflates 
prices, or the vanity-driven Brussels to Strasbourg and back again road 
circus which costs taxpayers around 200 million Euros every year. You 
couldn't make it up. And the UK will do nicely outside of the EU. The way 
the Europhiles talk you'd think we traded with no-one else. With an EU free 
trade agreement, and able to make our own free trade agreements elsewhere, 
not to mention being free of the burden of costly over-regulation, I think 
we'd prosper. And it shouldn't be forgotten that the EU needs us far more 
than we need it given that we have a £50+ billion trading deficit there. 
Perhaps we'd even be able to take back our fishing rights, who knows. We'd 
certainly regain control of our borders. I can smell the freedom already. :)
comments.author: dunholm1

comments.text:
+dunholm1 That poll is just as valid as the latest which shows the British 
people as pro-EU (63% for, 27% against, 10% undecided, 4% margin of error), 
don't act like you don't know how opinion polls work. I'm not joking when I 
say one actually showed a political party in Alberta wining a majority when 
it only go 10% of the vote.

"The EU has stagnated whilst others have forged ahead."

And who exactly has 'forged ahead'? China? The one that is currently is a 
municipal crisis since they have reached the limits of their economically 
unviable growth? India, with their massive wealth disparity which has a few 
million of them living a 1st world way of life and a billion who are not 
(and a quarter billion who live off the land with nothing else)? By 1st 
world standards (the only one that works for 1st world nations, odd isn't 
it?) the EU is doing fine. Why else would every modern nation in the 
Americas be trying to make a free trade deal with "a sinking ship"?

As for the Sinking ship analogy, just from a simple economic point of view 
even if the EU was sinking (it's not, but I don't have time to refute 
every half truth and out right lie), the UK leaving would be the equivalent 
of getting on a lifeboat with a hole the size of a Torries ego.
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+dave19941000 You appear to be confusing the statements of our politicians 
with the wishes of the British people. The latest opinion poll I 
saw indicated that over 50% want to leave, 35% want to stay, with the rest 
undecided. So over half of us simply want to leave, not renegotiate. We 
don't want "representation yet less integration", we want to go our own 
way. Cameron has absolutely no chance of negotiating any meaningful 
changes, and we all know it. The EU has stagnated whilst others have forged 
ahead. It's a fast-sinking ship and I don't want us to go down with it. 
Even Merkel seems to be coming to her senses, and not before time.
comments.author: dunholm1

comments.text:
+dunholm1"I want NO foreign interference in the governance of the UK"

Then you should be happy with the Status Quo, since you are getting just 
that with the current level of integration the UK has with the EU. No Euro, 
not in the Schengen Area, really it's just a glorified free trade agreement 
at this point an I'm suppressed more integrated members aren't pissed at 
the level of representation of members like the UK and others who want more 
representation yet less integration yet have such a vocal minority who are 
against the EU. Really the only ones who would are justified in being 
pissed off are the Germans, French and Benelux.
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+dave19941000 As I've already said, we could debate the specific points 
forever and neither one of us would change our minds. So let me put this as 
simply as I can - other than as regards our commitments to such as the UN, 
NATO etc, I want NO foreign interference in the governance of the UK 
without the stated agreement of the British people.
comments.author: dunholm1

comments.text:
+dunholm1 "they play the majority roll in the governance of Britain but are 
not elected by British people."

Less then 10% of all laws that are passed that effect Britain are from the 
European Parliament , you are, either deliberately or unintentionally, 
mixing up the UK and EUs Parliaments.

"As for the cost, are you denying that we are a net contributor? We pay in 
far more than we get back."

I never claimed otherwise, what I DID claim was the fact that the costs are 
outweighed by the benefits, just as the hundreds of millions spent on the 
monarchy each year are outweighed by the billions the economy benefits from 
it. Not all costs and benefits are measured by direct transaction between 
governments, if they where not a single country would open free trade deals 
with others.

"Immigrants must have a decent grasp of our language, and skills that the 
UK needs."

That would be a reasonable demand if it wasn't already the case for the 
most part.

"21% youth unemployment"

I'd make a joke about people from the 50s worrying about this, but this is 
a problem which has actually persisted in the UK since the 50s, and it 
stopping now would be the real shock.

"600,000 immigrants in receipt of benefits"

That is a lie and anyone who actually looks into the numbers would know 
that. Those 600,000 immigrants are what's called economically inactive, and 
only about 1.2% (at the most liberal count) of the social services budget 
is used on them. By comparison, 47.8% of the total population of the UK is 
classified as economically inactive, yet no one is talking about the nearly 
50% unemployment in the UK or how half of society is leaches. Why? Because 
those numbers can't be twisted as easily to make people believe 
unsubstantiated rhetoric.

"A clear majority now want out"

A clear majority also want in, that's the thing about poll numbers, they 
are bullshit and until the majority of Brits consistently vote no in them, 
instead of only half of them (where wording is everything, and not the 
actual intent), then you will have a point. Until then, the silent majority 
rules.

" UKIP policy is common sense."

If the numbers they stated where not twisted to give a false image of 
reality, you might have a point. Until the reality matches their rhetoric 
though, they are a fringe party who the common man should fear coming the 
power, and that's if it wasn't a one note party with an unelectable 
platform on the economy, social services and everything else that a 
government needs to plan for that isn't a referendum.
comments.author: dave19941000

comments.text:
+Alex Jenkins Evidence please? Secondly why should all nations have 
separate economic policies and separate currencies especially in a 
continent like Europe where all economies are heavily intertwined and 
massively reliant on one another for exports and imports. While it's 
certainly true that the Euro has been mismanaged (and this can still be 
amended) it doesn't detract from the sense  of having it. For one the Euro 
makes exchange costs 0 and a unified economic policy resulted in free trade 
across Europe. It is doubtful whether cross-border tariffs would have been 
reduced to the same degree if there wasn't a unified European policy. The 
removal of tariffs led to an economic boom post-ww2 in which Europe grew 
much faster than the United States. On balance it is probably better at the 
moment for a nation to retain its own currency (unless you are a very small 
state and burdened with a high deficit of course) however that doesn't 
change the fact that a properly managed Euro achieved through MORE European 
integration and a unified economic policy would be the best thing in Europe 
since VE day.
comments.author: Isaac Brock

comments.text:
All Nations should have their own currencies and their own monetary 
policies. The EU is a dictatorship, and everyone knows it.
comments.author: Alex Jenkins

comments.text:
+Alex Jenkins How exactly? How is coordinating foreign policy at EU level 
worse than coordinating it individually? Or how about if we had a 
coordinated economic policy there would not have been a Eurozone crisis or 
at least a crisis that was as deep. It's ludicrous for the ECB to run a 
single monetary policy and then allow nations to run separate fiscal 
policies.
comments.author: Isaac Brock

comments.text: its nonsensical to say that the EU doing it is better!
comments.author: Alex Jenkins

comments.text:
+Alex Jenkins That's exactly what I'm talking about. However in cases like 
foreign policy there should be coordination by the European parliament. 
It's nonsensical to argue that somehow isolated European states assuming 
different foreign policy decisions would be more effective than a unified 
EU wide strategy. This is precisely where the commission and where the 
parliament would be effective. There are obviously other areas where this 
would be necessary but that's a discussion for another day. There are other 
areas where obviously matters would be better off left to nation states to 
dictate for themselves. We're not arguing that ALL decisions should be

comments.text:
+jhutchyboy1 Oh god, the Daily Mail. Well, the first article uses the cost 
of public services (from Home Office) for each migrant and the absolute 
upper boundary (LSE - not Home Office - because it happens to be larger) to 
arrive at the largest possible figure in terms of cost, without deducting 
the contribution that illegal migrants make to the economy. So that figure 
is essentially meaningless.

The second article refers to a one-off event to which the UK government had 
to improvise a response. Asylum seekers are not routinely put up in 5 star 
hotels. It is not relevant and certainly not appropriate to refer to when 
considering immigration policy which occurs on a much, much, much larger 
scale. The actual experience of the average immigrant does not tell this 
lie that they have it better than the locals. That is totally ridiculous. 
There is no reason for it to be this way.

Most importantly, neither of those articles (because of the Daily Mail's 
conservative, racial, upper middle class bias) refer to the fact that a 
large proportion of illegal immigrants to the UK are genuinely seeking 
asylum for genuine reasons. I find the clamour to close the door to these 
people particularly callous. The UK, by the way, is required to afford them 
the opportunity to apply for asylum under international law, not EU law, so 
leaving the EU would have no affect on this.

The UK is also not part of the Schengen Area and is free to set the border 
controls as it sees fit, despite the House of Lords recommending it become 
part of Schengen. So the whole issue of the EU with regard to immigration 
is utterly irrelevant.

No country on Earth follows survival of the fittest. No individual on Earth 
follows survival of the fittest. Cooperation is the human world. How on 
Earth do you think the global economy works? Do you think countries 
extract, produce, develop, buy and sell products and labour entirely within 
their own borders? Or that they compete for a generalised pool of 
resources? It is almost entirely the opposite of this.

'Fixing things' in the UK is all very noble. The EU providing market 
access, greater regional and therefore global relevance, better access to 
more resources, a larger pool of highly-qualified labour - an increasing 
number of whom speak English - and continent-wide legislative and 
administrative capacity which increase economic capacities across the 
board. In providing all this, what exactly is the EU stopping the UK from 
fixing? Need I remind you that it all comes for a nominal fee - the UK 
contribution to the EU is TINY (less than a half of one percent of GDP, and 
1.1% of UK trade to the EU). If the UK left the EU the increased budget 
would be basically unnoticeable and completely eclipsed by the instant drop 
in GDP as trade takes a hit.

Troops in Afghanistan is foreign security policy and nothing to do with the 
EU.

The 'actual governments'? The EU is also an 'actual' government, you 
realise this, right? It might not look or feel familiar to you, but it is a 
government. And, yes, as I explained, the people of Europe do have a say in 
all of the EU laws - each and every one - through their MEPs. The 
Commissioners - what you are talking about when you mention the officials 
not directly elected by the people - do not fulfill the role of legislator 
and are rather policy-makers and administrative oversight. This might be 
unfamiliar to the role of a politician as you understand from Westminster, 
Maybe if you read up on what their day-to-day roles are you would realise 
that the idea that they are a threat to democracy is nonsense.

Yes, some vacuum cleaners and light bulbs have become subject to EU-wide 
legislation. This would, in all likelihood, have happened at the UK level 
eventually. It would have taken more time because the UK government is 
slower with this type of legislation, and more environmental damage would 
have been done. You do realise, also, that this legislation is 
environmentally - an economically - beneficial, right? Can't see a negative 
argument here.

Cameron is promising the referendum for political reasons. The people speak 
and those in power do actually have to listen, even if they disagree, which 
Cameron does. This does not mean it is a good idea. It does not even mean 
it is close to a good idea. It certainly does not, somehow, mean it is a 
good idea for the people, as you argue. If you leave the EU you will see, 
or you will keep blaming the UK's problems on things which don't actually 
cause them, like 'illegals'.
comments.author: John McLean

comments.text:
Eu has straight forward laws and agreements. It's just that individual 
nations have individual interest, and sometimes they simply do no want what 
the rest of the majority wants. Since the EU still is sort of an 
inter-state agreement union, you need consensus in order to decide anything 
(unless it's an area where the states have already given mandate for the 
EU-parliament to decide on). So, as a result, you get opt-outs: states will 
vote for stuff they don't want if they get they option to opt-out of them. 
Hence, the never-ending asterisks and exceptions to treaties and rules.


The only way to fix this, to make straightforward laws, would be to create 
a federation, like in the US. But then the EU-states would cease to be 
individual states, and that's not something most people want.

comments.text:
+James T. Kirk Only Greece, Slovenia, Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia are 
member states, in the Balkans. Albania, Macedonia, Serbia, Kosovo and 
Bosnia-Herzegovina aren't members, but most are candidate member states, 
and might become members in the future. 
To become a member of the European Union, certain conditions have to be 
met. You have to adopt all the European legislation into your national (and 
regional, if needed) legislation, sign certain treaties, accept the borders 
of the other member states, or at least willing to negotiate peacefully 
with your fellow members, be accepted unanimously by all other member 
states, and last but not least, you have to ask, too.
Switzerland is not interested in joining, and won't be forced to join. 
Those smaller states are too small, and can't join either, although I don't 
remember the exact reason. 
Ukraine? Perhaps, one day. But it's not for the near future, that's for 
sure.

comments.text:
For the same reason countries such as Ecuador use the USD, without being a 
member state. Montenegro has no say in the monetary policy of the European 
Central Bank, as Ecuador has no say in the US Federal Reserve, but the 
latter can't stop them from using it. Others include East Timor, Palau, El 
Salvador among others.
The micronations of Andorra, Vatican, Monaco and San Marino are different, 
because they have the right to mint their own coins, often due to treaties 
from before the inception of the Euro. San Marino and the Vatican used the 
Italian Lire, but had the right to mint their own coins (mainly sold to 
collectors, of course), and Monaco had the same agreement with France. 
Andorra is the strange one out, previously, they used both the Spanish 
Peseta and the French Franc, it's only recently, they wanted some of the 
collector's money, too.

The USA was originally meant to be something like the EU: a confederacy of

ended up being provinces within a strong armed central government.﻿

comments.text:

Well, it's nice to hear that you Swiss have this "direct democracy" but we 
just don't have that, see? We have parliamentary democracies because our 
politicians think we're not smart enough to make political decisions but 
what they do not say out loud is that they don't want us to have any power. 
But I don't know why you are here defending the EU if you live in 
Switzerland. "Voting out the scumbags in my government"? Oh, i just love 
how you make it sound so easy. I'm just one of 17 million people of which 
some don't even know what to vote.
comments.author: nativesupport2

comments.text:
Unless you are a national of a country like Switzerland (which you are 
obviously not, as you've implied you are from a country which has the 
Euro), which has a direct democracy system, then you equally "don't have a 
say" in the politics of your own country. We elect people who we think will 
do and say in parliament the things we want to happen, but once they are 
elected, we have very little control over what they actually do or say, 
until we have the chance to vote them out again 4, 5, 6 years down the 
line. That's what democracy means in the vast majority of "democratic 
countries". And by the way, the choice to not hold a referendum on the Euro 
in many EU countries was a decision taken by each individual country, not 
mandated by the EU. So blame your country for a lack of a referendum, not 
the EU. Hey, you can always vote out the scumbags in your government who 
didn't let you have a referendum. That's democracy.
comments.author: stefansmith

comments.text:
+SwordSkill2
It's.... complicated.
In short, it's because of corruption (which, if you're Greek, you 
unfortunately will have heard of with the former government).
Bloomberg on this:
"Budget Deceptions
Doubts about Greece’s fiscal responsibility gained ground after the 
government of Costas Karamanlis in 2004 disclosed that its socialist 
predecessor had cheated on its euro-entry exam in 2000. The country was 
able to enter the currency bloc after claiming its deficit was less than 1 
percent of gross domestic product, well within the bloc’s 3 percent 
threshold.
European Commission reports have since revealed Greece’s budget hasn’t been 
within the 3 percent limit a single year since its accession."

However, even though this is true, this is *not* the main reason for the 
Greek economic crisis. The issue lies with the way spending and debts were 
increased while tax evasion lowered the state's income, and then we have 
the US housing bubble bursting and boom, here we are.

As a German citizen, I'd like to apologise on behalf of half my country, 
namely the idiots who are voting CDU and I sincerely hope that Greece will 
recover by leaving the Euro Zone. I whish they'd stay in the EU, but I 
doubt it and it's definitely relatable.

comments.text:
+Pedro4490 You're actually spot on here. The EU is only deemed a "fuck up" 
based on its poor economic performance which is linked simultaneously to 
the Euro and the decisions of larger states. For example, the Greek bailout 
took away any principles of sovereign decision making following the palace 
coup and a strict austerity regime was enforced. It has remained in force 
despite the obvious signs that it had backfired not just in Greece but 
across the ENTIRE Eurozone. Nations with greater flexibility in decision 
making, and in particular those outside the Euro which is the main tool of 
the ECB's hegemony over austerity, have performed much, much better than 
those subjected to German diktat.

Incidentally before the GFC the EU was averaging substantial growth rates, 
in particular during the 90s and early 2000s growth in the "new Easter 
Europe" was exponential, exports jumped by hundreds of percentage points 
and the GDP reflected that growth. During that time the EU was deemed a 
resounding success both socially and, to a lesser extent, economically. It 
is quite interesting that the label of "failure" is applied only in a time 
of crisis.

+Hullensian

Learn difference between *presidential and parliamentary system*. All 
governments are unelected by people btw, you cannot vote for Minister of 
Defense in USA, just like you cannot vote for Commissioner for 
Transportation in EU.

The difference is in presidential system (US) the president appoints the 
government, in parliamentary system (EU, most of Europe) the government is 
appointed by parliament.

PS: It's common practice in Parliamentary system that members of cabinet 
are usually also members of elected parliament, it's common practice but 
not a rule. While in US it's common rule that members of parliament are 
colleagues, friends, party members, totally unelected, unknown to public.

comments.text:
+mrdean171
you are very good at laying down facts without the wisdom to understand 
them. to make a massive point about the mongols being the catalyst to 
european domination and you arent incorrect however to somehow ridicule it 
is like everyone laughing at the US because if the spanish didnt fund an 
italian to get to india then the US wouldnt be a superpower, its a 
ridiculous argument and doesnt really do anything for anyone.

now more importantly while the mongols can be argued as the cause of 
european domination you are fundamentally misunderstanding the reason why. 
its not due to the fall of the various empires they destroyed half way 
around the world, firstly because to be a threat to europe they would have 
had to have conquered a bunch of others to even get there, secondly a bit 
of technology doesnt suddenly make a superpower or the rest of the world 
would have caught up to the west by now.

the true gift the mongols gave to europeans is the plague, it killed off a 
large chunk of the population (excess manpower) and forced technological 
innovation to compensate which was given a minor boost by the fall of the 
Byzantines and the knowledge from there (50 years or so). when you have 
innovation and the rule of law which is a hallmark of western civilization 
(magna carta) then things start going your way, China, India and the Middle 
east never had this so while they wouldnt have been easy pickings for the 
Europeans they would still have been outclassed in both tactics, wealth and 
technology when competing against European nations. This doesnt even 
mention the discovery and colonisation of the new world giving even greater 
wealth, income and now the ability for commoners to own land thus allowing 
population growth while not creating excess manpower (keeping the need for 
technology in demand).

also one very important part of European domination which is unrelated to 
the mongols is competition, China, India and to a lesser extent the middle 
east were basically 1 nation in their respective areas. they had no real 
desire to expand thus mostly killing any reason to need to advance to gain 
an edge in battle. Europeans on the other hand were at war for 99% of their 
existence. they managed to create a balance of power (purely through 
realpolitik not by design) which made none powerful enough to dominate 
while forcing them to innovate and invent to try to stay alive.

when you combine Competition, rule of law, innovation and a few other minor 
advantages then you get rapid advancement which when fighting against 
nations that dont have this is equal to domination.

the thing is that European nations for the most part still have these 
traits, its possible to make the argument that americans dont when you 
consider that celebrities get a slap on the wrist when they do drugs and 
normal people go to prison for life.

comments.text:
+fdsdh1 I do not agree. Trade is trade at its sole definition and does not 
discriminate between foreign or domestic trade. If anything, I think trade 
would improve by removing barriers which otherwise exist in foreign trade. 
This is what the EU has done, and has proven successful. If anything, 
foreign trade is a frightening but also exhilarating concept which can 
benefit economies, but also destroy them due to the uncertainty of demand 
and supply outside a Nation.

Regarding languages, seeing that English is becoming more and more popular 
and widely spoken, I don't think it will be a problem. English is very 
versatile and even allows vocabulary of other languages to be used within 
its very context while adhering to English grammar. English grammar as a 
whole is much simpler than grammar of other languages.

As for representatives, I think with the merging of various nations we 
would see the rise in e-democracy such that representatives would be 
elected online and proportional to a certain number of individuals. There's 
nothing wrong with 1 representative; or two; or a hundred, and thousands if 
needed. What's important is that people are being represented in Congress 
by someone whom they've elected to communicate their thoughts of any matter 
therein.

As for hierarchy of power, I think having presidents/PMs or whomever is 
head of government of their State to be able to elect a Chancellor of a 
Federation. Aye, e-democracy might just put an end to physical elections 
and so might be held online, thus it may be so such a powerful position 
could be directly elected by the people or elected through their heads of 
state.

Finally, ties would never be broken. Infact, a Commonwealth would become 
better integrated into a Federation since having a loose union of 
Commonwealth Nations does constitute as a Confederation insofar that its 
evolution to a Federation allows it to enjoy much or greater powers within 
such a framework as detailed by any ratified Constitution thereof.

comments.text:
+Matt Beechey 5 false arguments. let me explain. it doesn't matter what the 
BoE has done. just look at the exchange rates. if the BoE had to print

money supply goes up. which is exactly what happened. british banks didn't 
have more money than french banks. this is simply a false argument. 
compellingly simple but not based on any facts.
2. you can have different economies with one currency. it's amazing how 
this fallacy is still viral in the UK. do you think nobody ever thought 
that through and some UKIP back benchers are cleverer than the rest of the 
world? do you believe internet trolls in the comment section of news papers 
or why do you repeat that nonsense? europe joins a monetary union and you 
guys think nobody every thought about the most basic question? that so 
simplistic and populistic. well here we go. I can explain it only briefly. 
it's entirely possible to have a monetary union without any sort of fiscal 
exchange. the theory is simple. if you can't adjust exchange rates and 
inflation because there are no exchange rates within a currency and the 
inflation is managed by economic principles and not political agendas, you 
simply adjust different economies by the price of labor and goods. it's 
that simple. if the greeks are only half as productive as germans they only 
get half their wages. right now they think they are entitled to more 
because of the debt fueled boom but sooner or later people will work for 
less pay and the economy will be competitive again and the prices for goods 
will drop. also the prices for flats and houses, everything really. there 
is no need to screw around with anything. the marked takes care of that. 
you can't make a single argument why greece and germany can't have one 
currency. there is none. but when the greeks fuck up their economy (like 
they did a lot over the centuries) then they will fail. nothing to do with 
the euro or the theory.
3. if france falls into a recession the euro would hardly drop, but even if 
it would drop a lot, it would be good for greece and spain. yes they have 
an imbalance and they are net importers but a weak euro would be perfect 
for them. they would gain competitiveness and their products would be 
cheaper. so either way it makes hardly a difference because pros and cons 
cancel each other out. cheaper imports or cheaper exports. doesn't matter 
that much.

look, there is no real value in screwing around with exchange rates, 
inflation and any of that. the theories all say that inflation at 2% 
percent is a one fits all standard and politics only gets in the way. so 
the euro is prefect for keeping short lived political ambitions out and 
economic need in. the money supply is provided by central banks and they 
don't care about how many countries are there or how their economies are 
doing. that has no implications for them. you can't name a single one. 
central banks adjust by looking at what is there (money in it's various 
forms) at the moment and one currency is as good as the next, no matter the 
amount of countries involved. it's like london and the midlands.  they 
share the pound but the BoE still adjusts only according to one indicator, 
the amount of money.
4. a budged is vastly different from the pure economics. run a deficit or 
not. simply adjust taxes or spending. that's almost purely political. you 
can build less new roads and spend less on pensioners or the military. you 
can raise taxes by 2% without doing any harm to the economy. if france 
didn't want to run a deficit, they could get their act together. the franc 
wouldn't save them in this situation either and the euro is not the 
problem. 
5. the pound is stronger so what? do you think the value of 1 in any 
currency matters? the pound was stronger the day the euro was created and 
the exchange rates didn't change much. didn't you read my comment or don't 
you understand that? if the exchange rates had changed massively without 
the economies reflecting this, that would be notable. but nothing changed. 
that just shows that the UK could have joined the euro in 2001 and nothing 
would be different. they could tie the pound to the euro (almost the chase 
anyway)  with a fixed exchange mechanism and this time around it would work 
without political interference.

comments.text:
As Matt said, it was quite prudent of Parliament to refuse to take up the 
Euro, since there are some countries in the Eurozone that are somewhat 
irresponsible with how they deal with their economy (Greece, Spain, 
Portugal, and Italy). These countries caused major problems in the Eurozone 
during the depression of the early 21st century, but the UK wasn't hit as 
hard because we used a different currency. We weren't impervious to it, 
however, and as a nation we still felt some of the heat from the European 
crisis. There is a near endless list of pros and cons to the decision to 
have a single currency in Europe; the media tends to just focus on the 
crises and problems that stem from the Eurozone, while very few actually 
portray the positives.

was a professional essay. However that still doesn't mean that no time 
should be dedicated to basic fucking grammar and syntax.

top_comment.text: Sweden does not have an Opt-Out.﻿
top_comment.author: SilverWave

comments.text:
+SilverWave Sweden has never had an Opt-out for the Eurozone. Denmark and 
the United Kingdom obtained special opt-outs in the original Maastricht 
Treaty. Both countries are legally exempt from joining the eurozone unless 
their governments decide otherwise, either by parliamentary vote or 
referendum. Sweden, which joined the EU in 1995 after the Maastricht Treaty 
was signed, is required to join the eurozone under the terms of its 
accession treaty as soon as it fulfils the convergence criteria, which 
include being part of ERM II for two years. However, the Swedish people 
turned down euro adoption in a 2003 referendum and since then the country 
has intentionally avoided fulfilling the adoption requirements by not 
joining ERM II, which is voluntary.spanish greetings

comments.text:
+111q222p333m444z What makes you think that I'm "hostile" to Scottish 
independence? I clearly said that I don't really care. If the Scots want to 
leave the Union, so be it. Peeved, though, that they get a referendum on 
their future, but the rest of us are denied one on ours. And I wouldn't say 
that the Scots "are ruled by foreigners" whilst in the Union. In fact, 
they've had a disproportionate influence. Off the top of my head - Blair, 
Brown, Reid, Darling, Dewar, Alexander, Cook, and on it goes. Even 
Cameron claims Scottish ancestry. And a fine mess they've gotten us into! 
The promise by Cameron of a referendum (sense of deja vu here for some 
reason) is, if memory serves, based on him being PM after the next 
election, not on the Tories winning it. Get out of jail free card if ever I 
saw one. He has broken practically every manifesto pledge he made, and is 
simply not to be trusted. His party is collapsing under him. Membership has 
plummeted, ward associations are closing, and activists are no longer 
active. I'll be surprised if he's still PM BEFORE the next election, never 
mind after it. His own MPs are in almost-open revolt and fearing for their 
jobs. I didn't think I could ever despise anyone as much as I despise 
Blair, but Cameron has moved to the top of my list. No, the EU does not 
have the power to order a referendum. My point was that a benign and 
democratically-minded EU could and should have added its voice to the 
debate and supported the idea. However, it seems to be doing everything in 
its power to dissuade us from holding one. But it has "form" in this 
direction, not least with its habit of not taking "no" for an answer. And 
that of itself is indicative.
comments.author: dunholm1

comments.text:
+dunholm1
The rest of the UK won't have to reapply for EU membership if Scotland 
leaves - it will be the successor state to the old UK, and will therefore 
inherit any treaties or international obligations it had. Scotland will 
have to apply for membership because it will be a new state.

You sound somewhat hostile to the idea of Scottish independence, but don't 
you think that contradicts your belief in the independence of nation 
states? If you think Britain should be independent of the EU, why shouldn't 
Scotland be independent of the UK? You can't tell me people shouldn't be 
'ruled by foreigners', yet claim the Scots should remain in a political 
union with the English, Welsh and Northern Irish.

In my opinion the economic difference made to Scotland will be minor - 
based on what I know, there will probably be slight economic difficulties 
to begin with but Scotland will likely soon prosper. If they use their oil 
to create a sovereign wealth fund like Norway they could become very rich. 
Most importantly, they'll be able to set their own policy decisions and 
maintain access to the EU's markets, which the UK may leave.

I personally would prefer they stay in the UK for now, but I can understand 
why they want to go. In the long-term I think it would be good for England, 
Wales and Scotland to be separate states with more powers over their own 
affairs (Northern Ireland is more complicated) within a wider European 
federation. The UK is far too centralized, even with devolution.

We will be getting a referendum in 2017 - Cameron has promised one, and I 
reckon Labor will at some point too as it could steal the 2015 election for 
them given the unpopularity of the coalition partners and the rise of UKIP. 
The only reason we haven't had a vote since 1975 is because the issue 
hasn't been as prominent as it is today. Referendums are only used in the 
UK to placate the people when their rage boils over, and the EU doesn't 
have the power to set national referendums so that's a moot point.
comments.author: 111q222p333m444z

comments.text:
+111q222p333m444z I don't know what to think about Scottish independence, 
so diverse and contradictory are the "facts" presented by either side of 
the debate. Then again, my views may be less than impartial as I have had 
first-hand experience of the anti-English attitudes prevalent in that 
country. And at a time when we have the worst politicians in living memory 
the smug superiority and arrogance of Salmond still manages to shine 
through. I suppose the bottom line is that I don't care. It's true that 
without the Scots we English are less likely to have the likes of Brown, 
Blair or Miliband foisted upon us, but with the alternative being 
the Cameron's of this world - - -. So let them go their own way if that is 
what they wish. There will be a period of upheaval, then the rest of the 
UK will chug merrily along, as always. I'm not sure what will happen to our 
EU membership as I've heard conflicting opinions, but if the Scots have to 
re-apply for membership as seems likely then it stands to reason that so do 
the rest of us - and won't that put the cat among the pigeons. With a 
rapidly-growing number against continued membership it is going to take a 
brave politician to go cap-in-hand to the EU in the face of so much 
opposition. The demand for an immediate referendum will become 
unstoppable. It beggars belief that we have been denied one thus far, and 
this only adds to my anger. In fact, it could be said that a benign and 
democratic EU should itself be demanding that we have one. But hell will 
freeze over before that happens.
comments.author: dunholm1

comments.text:
+dunholm1
Well the British *are* Europeans, whether you like it or not. Saying we 
aren't European is like saying Japanese people aren't Asian. It's like 
saying a Victoria Sponge isn't a cake - we fit the criteria down to every 
detail. I think we could put the European interest first if we were a 
little more brotherly and egalitarian-minded towards our cousins on the 
continent.

I don't see how being in a union with the rest of Europe affects our 
freedom. We weren't exactly free men in the days before democracy when we 
were ruled by monarchs, aristocrats, the land-owning gentry and the Church 
in a heavily stratified class-based society of rulers and peasants - yet we 
were independent.

The size of a state is irrelevant; its nature is what matters. Henry the 
VIII ruled a small country but he did so as a tyrant with an iron fist. 
Barack Obama leads a huge nation yet is relatively humane and his powers 
are limited.

I don't see how it affects our culture or identity either. Like I said 
earlier, has being British made you feel any less English? If so, is that a 
bad thing? If not, why do you fear Europe taking away your identity when 
Britain hasn't? There is no reason for us to stop speaking English or 
anything like that.

Hell, our culture is more Americanized these days anyway. Culture is 
becoming increasingly obsolete as globalisation and individualism take 
precedence, and overall I think that's a good thing. Culture is often a 
kind of social tyranny - for example think of how women in the Middle East 
are treated - getting rid of culture gives people more choice and more 
freedom, and enables them to question unjust traditions.

I don't buy the idea that we've always had to fight to defend our freedom. 
In pretty much all major wars we fought, from Napoleon to WW2, we were the 
ones who declared war on our enemies. We probably could've stayed out of 
them and filled the English Channel with warships, yet we intervened for 
economic and imperialistic reasons.

Regardless, that is history now. I'd rather we not live in the past, 
especially since the past was pretty awful for the average Briton. I don't 
think freedom has been a big thing here in the past - true democracy is 
fairly new in Britain, and for the last 300 years we were focused more on 
global imperialism - i.e. taking away other people's freedom.

It's good that we've turned away from that and given our own citizens power 
and rights, but let's not pretend freedom was an integral part of our 
culture. We are not Americans - our history is one of much oppression. 
Again, we didn't even have human right until we signed up to the ECHR 
(European Convention on Human Rights).

'Better red that dead' - that's actually my thoughts exactly. I don't want 
Europe to be dominated by Russia, China and the US. I want us to be free 
and independent. We're too small and insignificant on our own to achieve 
that, and the common interest binds us Europeans together.

It will increasingly be an issue as a growing China, declining US and 
resurgent Russia wage a new Cold War for influence. The EU will be a part 
of that, with or without the UK, and in the latter case we will end up as a 
vassal to either the US or the EU. Without the EU, Europe will be at the 
mercy of these superpowers.

Being part of Europe is only handing over our country to 'foreign control' 
if you view Europeans as 'foreign'. I don't see them this way; I feel we 
have shared interests and a shared European identity, in particular amongst 
younger Europeans. We are not living in 1939 anymore; the world has moved 
on a great deal!

Bear in mind a huge number of people working in EU intuitions are British, 
and one of the three most powerful voices in the Union is British (David 
Cameron). Scottish, Irish and Welshmen are also 'foreigners' to the English 
whether or not you see them that way.

That doesn't meant we can't have a shared identity and work together for 
the common good, while maintaining our unique culture and values (although 
as I said I personally dislike the concept of culture, as your viewpoint 
shows it is needlessly divisive).

The way Britain functions is evidence enough that Europe can too, and as 
the common interest becomes stronger it will become inevitable just as the 
building of the UK was. Europe will be united just as India was, and that 
is just as culturally and ethnically diverse as Europe. As is China.

I don't see other Europeans as foreign to me, just as I don't see Scotsman 
as foreign. I know they both are on some level, but I don't care. I am 
English, I am British and I am European. I like being part of all of these 
societies. My attitude to the EU is the same as Cameron's to the UK - 
'better together.' What is your opinion on Scottish independence?
comments.author: 111q222p333m444z

comments.text:
+111q222p333m444z The Welsh etc are Brits and could be expected to put the 
best interests of Britain first. And whoever is elected, and whatever their 
nationality or party, if they fail to please then we Brits have the power 
to remove them from office at the next election. This is not the case with 
90% of MEPs. Someone said on here a while ago "We don't need another 
referendum on closer integration with Europe. We had one around 1939 and we 
voted "no"". That resonated with me because in my mind this is about more 
than just economics or trade and the like, however important these 
things are. It's visceral. From Trafalgar to Waterloo, from the Armada to 
the two World Wars, Brits have had to fight and die to keep these islands 
free from continental dominance. We are "les Anglo-Saxonnes" and while we 
are part of Europe we have not been of it for centuries. Most of us don't 
hate the continentals but we do have a healthy distrust built primarily on 
history. We have grown our own island identity and we are proud of that 
identity. We also place freedom above almost all else, possibly because 
we've had to fight so often to keep it. Our American cousins summed it up 
nicely with the Cold War phrase of "better dead than red". There's that 
Anglo-Saxon love of freedom again. So whatever the benefits perceived by 
some, I will never see myself as a European. I'm a freedom-loving Brit who 
does not want these islands handed over to foreign control without our 
agreement, and without a shot being fired.
