comments.text:
+dunholm1
I know this is a late reply - sorry about that - but I will address your 
points as best I can.

Power in the EU is mostly held by the European Council - the elected heads 
of government of the member states. They decide the policies and set the 
agenda for the Union. The Commission simply implements their decisions - it 
is no different to how the UK civil service implements government policy. 
they too are unelected, as our our Lords (and our monarch). The European 
Parliament votes on every law, so our representatives make the law. It 
decides on the EU budget. The Parliament also approves the Commission, and 
has the power to remove them from office. It could do with some more powers 
- initiating laws would be one - and ideally the Commission should be made 
up of sitting MEPs.

These things will happen as the EU evolves from a mere economic union into 
a proper federation; right now as member states have most of the power, the 
democratic deficit isn't too problematic (though it is increasingly an 
issue as the EU receives more powers). If the EU had the powers of a 
national government it would be fair to say it was too unaccountable, but 
right now the scope of its power is very limited. Any criticism of the EU 
could be levied at any other international organization with some degree of 
power, like the IMF or NATO.

I think most people would argue for decentralized power wherever it is 
applicable, but what I care about more than anything is the rights and 
freedoms of the individual. A large centralized government isn't 
necessarily a bad thing - just look at the US. It is a federation of 50 
states, each comparable to a European nation, with a population of 
300,000,000 people. They are generally a free, prosperous people and they 
almost all support federalism and unity. Why can't we have that? Why can't 
we reap the rewards they reap without descending into some kind of 
totalitarian regime? Europeans are not keen on totalitarian regimes as the 
Russians or Chinese are.

The US federal government is not as strong as, say, the UK government. The 
states manage most of their affairs, and I see no reason for Europe to do 
things differently. Less centralized power can be a bad thing for the 
people; for example, without federal laws protecting minorities many states 
would ban things like homosexuality or interracial marriages. There would 
be legal segregation, atheists and minority religions would be 
discriminated against, reproductive rights for women would be outlawed. The 
US federal government protects people from state tyranny. Let's not forget 
that the UK had no human rights legislation before we adopted the ECHR.

I don't see centralized power as tantamount to dictatorship because of the 
many examples where it clearly isn't, and the important thing to bare in 
mind is scale. The EU may be a bigger beast than the UK, but the European 
people are a much bigger collective than the British people. Bare in mind 
the fact that a centralized EU government is never going to be a heavily 
centralized government of a unitary European superstate like China - it 
will be at best a loose federation like the US. It will be democratic, 
capitalist and the people will be free. Otherwise it will collapse. No 
country in the Union wants a dictatorship so why would they build one? Why 
would they surrender power to it? They want what America has, nothing more. 
Let's not forget the UK is a union of countries, and not even a federation 
- we are a unitary state. Yet we are not a totalitarian state.

Churchill advocated a United States of Europe passionately, and while it's 
true that he spoke of Britain being separate from it, this was back when we 
still had the Empire. Churchill thought the Empire could survive the post 
WW2 era but he was wrong - it collapsed, and we ceased to be a great power 
like the US or USSR. Since those days, Britain's interests have been less 
our own and more so in line with the rest of Europe. It is only interests 
both corporate and geopolitical injected into this country by the US that 
make us different, and these aren't our interests - they are Uncle Sam's 
interests.

It's not fair to say that the UK has no influence in the Union. We are one 
of the Big Three, and we decide a great deal of policy. Often we hold the 
deciding balance of power, as we tend to side with Germany more on 
economics and France on geopolitics. They often oppose each other on these 
issues.

Much of the EU's financial policies and regulations were British 
suggestions, and the idea of expanding the Union to Eastern Europe was a 
result of British pressure. France and Germany wanted the Union to be made 
up of just rich Western states for a more stable federal union, while the 
UK wanted the EU to gobble up Eastern Europe to undermine Russia's 
influence, expand capitalism and please the US by growing NATO. We also 
thought the Eastern states would destabilize the EU and thus slow things 
down, preventing federalism. That's why we're still banging on about Turkey 
joining - it would but the final nail in the federal coffin.

The UK has had a lot more influence than people realize because our media 
is very hostile to the EU and focuses on all the negative aspects, real or 
imagined.  British farmers do well out of the CAP but it is something that 
could do with reform. The moving of the Parliament is universally unpopular 
across the Union - even the people of France think its stupid - I don't 
think it will last. It's a trivial thing really; we could equally complain 
about all the money wasted in the UK on the monarchy for it's pointless 
symbolism.

Let's just say hypothetically the EU is a federal state, like the US. It is 
as free and democratic as the US - perhaps more so - and the whole Union is 
relatively prosperous. Would you be in favor of that? If not I want to know 
why, because I often hear criticism of the EU as it is today (much of it 
legitimate, and concerns I share), but I think the impassioned hostility 
stems more from a rejection of pan-Europeanism, and I want to know why 
people don't like that concept. I assure you, no Euro-federalist like 
myself is also pro-dictatorship. We want to reform the EU rather than 
disband it.
comments.author: 111q222p333m444z

comments.text:
+dunholm1
I too am glad we're able to have a civil discussion - normally I'm 
bombarded with insults, which I feel is counterproductive to any discourse. 
I appreciate this kind of respectful disagreement.

I believe in Independence too, but independence has its limits. The smaller 
a nation is, the less it is able to assert its own interests and resist the 
influence of larger powers.

We've already seen this in the UK - our foreign policy has practically been 
set in Washington DC since WW2, particularly in the last decade. We have 
extradition treaties with the US that enable them to take any UK citizen, 
yet the reverse is not true. We have American troops based here, using us 
as a base for their wars. We're completely dependent on the US for our 
nuclear deterrent (unlike the French). We're practically a vassal state of 
America's empire, and this is the result of us being dependent on the 
larger power.

The other EU countries don't want to be part of some American empire - they 
do value their independence. They see the EU as a way of pooling 
sovereignty to make Europe independent once more. It's time we ceased being 
a mere sphere of influence for the US, Russia and now increasingly China to 
fight over. I don't want us to be the victims of the next wave of 
imperialism, especially after just coming out of the World Wars and the 
Cold War.

I would like for England to be part of a loose federation of European 
nations, autonomous on most things but sharing power with the rest of 
Europe on issues where it is sensible and reasonable to do so. I want the 
federal government to be heavily restricted by a written constitution and 
democratically elected by the people. I want the Parliament to have more 
power, while the current EU leaders (the heads of national governments) 
take the role of US state governors, focusing on the national politics of 
their member states.

We don't need to cease being Englishmen within Europe anymore than being 
British makes us any less English. The flag can stay, the language can stay 
(in fact English would most likely be the main language of the Union), the 
Queen can stay - even the pound can probably stay.

I must stress that I want a loose federation, not a heavily centralized 
unitary superstate. I don't think many people want the latter option. My 
ideal would be an even looser union than the US - shared borders, shared 
foreign policy, shared currency, (though we may opt out as we do now) 
shared constitutional rights and a single federal tax to pay for things 
like defense and EU-wide infrastructure projects. In fact I could support 
some powers the EU has now being repatriated to national governments (such 
an perhaps environmental policies).

I don't even see federalism as necessarily mandatory for all states - a 
core federation could exist within a looser two-tier European Union, with 
member states like the UK and Sweden staying out of the federation but 
remaining in the Union, retaining their currencies, their own taxes and 
armed forced but participating in the single market, a military alliance 
and other shared programs. There are plenty of options for Europe, but 
sticking together and working as a team is what matters.

I can't see a federal union happening without a democratic government like 
the US. It would be far too unstable - it'd collapse almost immediately. 
The USSR only managed to stay united for as long as it did because of the 
overwhelming power of Russia (it was basically a continuation of the 
Russian empire), which constituted half the population and economy of the 
Soviet Union, and even then it collapsed. Germany could not keep a far 
larger totalitarian union together (nor would they have any wish to do so).

People often forget that when comparing the EU to the USSR - it's apples to 
oranges really. One was a Russian dominated communist empire, the other is 
a very loose capitalist union of democratic nations that are much more 
equal in size - even the largest (Germany) makes up only 16% of the total 
EU population. A dictatorship is unwanted and couldn't even hope to 
maintain stability. The member states realize this, and have no wish to 
surrender power to a dictatorship anyway.

Right now we are in a position much like the US during the Articles of 
Confederation period (the Eurozone crises in particular resembles the 
economic hardships of the early looser American union) and we're faced with 
the need to pursue further integration. But like America (and unlike the 
USSR), we have the values, the political infrastructure and the will as a 
people to build a democratic union.

Well, outside the UK anyway. My kind are admittedly a rare breed on these 
fair isles. I do think if we're not going to sign up to the federation we 
will have to bail out eventually - we can't keep slowing it down for 
everyone else when they want to carry on at a much faster pace. It's not 
fair on us or them.

But still, I personally believe in the European dream so I'll speak up for 
it as long as it remains a prominent issue in the political sphere of our 
country. You must do the same for your vision of our future, because that 
is what free speech is all about. It ensures anyone who believes they have 
the right idea can share it with the people and see if it can stand up to 
public scrutiny.

After the debate has been had a vote must follow. I do support that, even 
though I'd expect to lose it. Democracy means you don't always get your 
way, but it's still important to stand up for what you believe in. Sorry to 
bombard you with all my rambling.
comments.author: 111q222p333m444z

captions.text:
Where, is the European Union? Obviously here
somewhere, but much like the the European

continent itself, which has an unclear boundary,
the European Union also has some fuzzy edges
to it.

To start, the official members of the European
Union are, in decreasing order of population:

* Germany
* France

* The United Kingdom
* Italy

* Spain
* Poland

* Romania
* The Kingdom of the Netherlands

* Greece
* Belgium

* Portugal
* The Czech Republic

* Hungary
* Sweden

* Austria
* Bulgaria

* Denmark
* Slovakia

* Finland
* Ireland

* Croatia
* Lithuania

* Latvia
* Slovenia

* Estonia
* Cyprus

* Luxembourg
* Malta

The edges of the EU will probably continue
to expand further out as there are other countries
in various stages of trying to become a member.

How exactly the European Union works is hideously
complicated and a story for another time,

but for this video you need know only three
things:
1. Countries pay membership dues and
2. Vote on laws they all must follow and

3. Citizens of member countries are automatically
European Union citizens as well

This last means that if you're a citizen of
any of these countries you are free to live

and work or retire in any of the others. Which
is nice especially if you think your country

is too big or too small or too hot or too
cold. The European Union gives you options.

By the way, did you notice how all three of
these statements have asterisks attached to

this unhelpful footnote? Well, get used to
it: Europe loves asterisks that add exceptions
to complicated agreements.

These three, for example, point us toward
the first bit of border fuzziness with Norway,

Iceland and little Liechtenstein. None of
which are in the European Union but if you're

a EU citizen you can live in these countries
and Norwegians, Icelanders, or Liechtensteiner(in)s
can can live in yours.

Why? In exchange for the freedom of movement
of people they have to pay membership fees

to the European Union -- even though they
aren't a part of it and thus don't get a say
its laws that they still have to follow.

This arrangement is the European Economic
Area and it sounds like a terrible deal, were

it not for that asterisk which grants EEA
but not EU members a pass on some areas of

law notably farming and fishing -- something
a country like Iceland might care quite a
lot about running their own way.

Between the European Union and the European
Economic Area the continent looks mostly covered,

with the notable exception of Switzerland
who remains neutral and fiercely independent,

except for her participation in the Schengen
Area.

If you're from a country that keeps her borders
extremely clean and / or well-patrolled, the

Schengen Area is a bit mind-blowing because
it's an agreement between countries to take
a 'meh' approach to borders.

In the Schengen Area international boundaries
look like this: no border officers or passport

checks of any kind. You can walk from Lisbon
to Tallinn without identification or need
to answer the question: "business or pleasure?".

For Switzerland being part of Schengen but
not part of the European Union means that

non-swiss can check in any time they like,
but they can never stay.

This koombaya approach to borders isn't appreciated
by everyone in the EU: most loudly, the United

Kingdom and Ireland who argue that islands
are different. Thus to get onto these fair
isles, you'll need a passport and a good reason.

Britannia's reluctance to get fully involved
with the EU brings us to the next topic: money.

The European Union has its own fancy currency,
the Euro used by the majority, but not all

of the European Union members. This economic
union is called the Eurozone and to join a

country must first reach certain financial
goals -- and lying about reaching those goals
is certainly not something anyone would do.

Most of the non-Eurozone members when they
meet the goals, will ditch their local currency

in favor of the Euro but three of them Denmark,
Sweden and, of course, the United Kingdom,

have asterisks attracted to the Euro sections
of the treaty giving them a permanent out-out.

And weirdly, four tiny European countries
Andorra, San Marino, Monaco & Vatican City

have an asterisk giving them the reverse:
the right print and use Euros as their money,

despite not being in the European Union at
all.

So that's the big picture: there's the EU,
which makes all the rules, the Eurozone inside

it with a common currency, the European Economic
Area outside of it where people can move freely

and the selective Schengen, for countries
who think borders just aren't worth the hassle.

As you can see, there's some strange overlaps
with these borders, but we're not done talking

about complications by a long shot one again,
because empire.

So Portugal and Spain have islands from their
colonial days that they've never parted with:

these are the Madeira and Canary Islands are
off the coast of Africa and the Azores well

into the Atlantic. Because these islands are
Spanish and Portuguese they're part of the
European Union as well.

Adding a few islands to the EU's borders isn't
a big deal until you consider France: the

queen of not-letting go. She still holds onto
a bunch of islands in the Caribbean, Reunion

off the coast of Madagascar and French Guiana
in South America. As far as France is concerned,

these are France too, which single handedly
extends the edge-to-edge distance of the European
Union across a third of Earth's circumference.

Collectively, these bits of France, Spain
and Portugal are called the Outermost Regions

-- and they're the result of the simple answer
to empire: just keep it.

On the other hand, there's the United Kingdom,
the master of maintaining complicated relationships

with her quasi-former lands -- and she's by
no means alone in this on such an empire-happy
continent.

The Netherlands and Denmark and France (again)
all have what the European Union calls Overseas

Territories: they're not part of the European
Union, instead they're a bottomless well of

asterisks due to their complicated relationships
with both with the European Union and their

associated countries which makes it hard to
say anything meaningful about them as a group
but...

in general European Union law doesn't apply
to these places, though in general the people

who live there are European Union citizens
because in general they have the citizenship

of their associated country, so in general
they can live anywhere in the EU they want

but in general other European Union citizens
can't freely move to these territories.

Which makes these places a weird, semipermeable
membrane of the European Union proper and

the final part we're going to talk about in
detail even though there are still many, more

one-off asterisks you might stumble upon,
such as: the Isle of Man or those Spanish

Cities in North Africa or Gibraltar, who pretends
to be part of Southwest England sometimes,

or that region in Greece where it's totally
legal to ban women, or Saba & friends who

are part of the Netherlands and so should
be part of the EU, but aren't, or the Faeroe

Islands upon which while citizens of Denmark
live they lose their EU citizenship, and on
and on it goes.

These asterisks almost never end, but this
video must.
